fields.name: Services
fields.title: Services
fields.paragraphs:
ESDI stands in the forefront of the international effort to restore the habitability of the Horn of Africa. We offer our clients contextualized information that take into account the intricate relationship between the environment, social values and governance systems in the region. We provide our clients and local governments both sectoral and integrated knowledge that can inform public policy and guide strategic interventions. 

While enhancing regional knowledge, we empower the peoples of the region through education and capacity building training. We provide them the tools necessary to identify the drivers of instability in the region, and show them how to tackle them.

#### We offer our clients and the local stakeholders seminars and workshops on: 

+ Risk mitigation strategies 
+ Practical adaptation and coping methods 
+ Institution building 
+ Good governance 
+ Conflict resolution 
+ Sustainable community development

fields.name: Hassan O. Mahadallah, PhD
fields.long_description:
Curriculum Vitae

### Professional Preparation


+ PHD – 1997 Tulane University, New Orleans, Louisiana
+ MA – 1985 Baylor University, Waco, Texas
+ BA –1983 Rust College, Holly Springs, Mississippi

### Appointments


+ 2010 – Present Professor, Dept. of Political Science -- SUBR
+ 2009 – 2010	Interim chair, Dept. of Public Administration– SUBR
+ 2005 – 2010 Assoc. Prof., Dept. of Political Science – SUBR
+ 1998 - 2005 Asst. Prof., Dept. of Political Science – SUBR
+ 1995 – 1998 Visiting Prof., Dept. of Political Science – SUBR
+ 1992 – 1995 Adj. Prof., Evening and Weekend College – SUNO

### Sample of Publications


1.	“History of Somalia’s Armed Forces,” in Kurt Piehler, ed., Encyclopedia of Military Science (Sage), forthcoming
2.	“Continuity and Change in U.S. Foreign Policy,” Horn of Africa, Vol. 27 (2009), pp. 36-63.
3.	“Islamic Courts, Ethiopia’s Intervention in Somalia, and Its Implications for Regional Stability,” Horn of Africa, Vol. XXV (2007), pp. 135-164.
4.	“Pithless Nationalism: The Somali Case,” in Abdi Kusow, ed., Putting the Cart Before the Horse (Trenton, NJ: Red Sea Press, 2004), pp. 59-74.
5.	“American Political Parties,” in D. Grier Stephenson, et al, Understanding American government (Redding, CA: Horizon Textbook Publishing, 2005).


### Sample of Research Presentations“


1.	“Effective Leadership and the Sustainability of the African State,” a paper presented at The First International Leadership Conference, Kampala, Uganda, 16-19 June 2010
2.	“Political Leadership in the Horn of Africa,” a paper presented at The Nordic African Institute, Uppsala, Sweden, 25-26 May 2010.
3.	“Challenges of Sustainability in the Horn of Africa,” a paper presented at the Seventh International Conference on Public Management, Policy and Development, Accra, Ghana, 13-24 June 2009.
4.	“Regional Determinants of U.S. Foreign Policy in Africa,” a paper presented at the King-Mandela Symposium, University of Georgia, fall, 2008.
5.	“Unsustainable Trends in the Horn of Africa,” a paper presented at the 2007 Triennial Conference of the Somali International Studies Association (SISA), Djibouti, Republic of Djibouti, 13-15 December 2007.

### Synergistic Activities

Nelson Mandela School of Public Policy and Urban Affairs: Dr. Mahadallah is an IGERT Professor and teaches Sustainability in the Ph.D. program. The IGERT program is a collaborative program between Southern University and Michigan Tech University. The mission of the programs is train graduate students in sustainability and multi-disciplinary decision making and education.

fields.name: Mohamed Hussein
fields.long_description:
Curriculum Vitae

### Mohamed Hussein

Experienced in addressing the root causes of Somalia's social, economic and political instabilities.
optimasoma@gmail.com

#### Experience

**Consultant at OPTIMA LOCAL PRACTITIONERS CONSULTANCY**
June 2013 - Present (3 years 10 months)
Managing Director

**Senior Consultant at Addadly Electric Power** *August 2016 - September 2016 (2 months)*

Provided consultancy services for Addedly Electric Power and produced concept paper, which was
successfully submitted on the behalf of the electricity provider compony to Development Alternative
Initiatives (DAI).

**Senior Consultant at Al Madina Hospital** *June 2016 - July 2016 (2 months)*

Provided strategic consultancy through concept paper for Al Madina Hospital.

**Lead Consultant at OPTIMA Somalia** March 2016 - May 2016 (3 months)

Through the promotion of inclusive markets, researched the best approach to creating value chain markets for
Somalia fishery sector.

**Lead Researcher at Addressing Root Causes Fund and (ARC) Consortioum** *February 2016 - February 2016 (1 month)*

On a short consultancy assignment, researched through context specific labor market analysis on the
lead causes of current rampant youth unemployment and major drivers of social, economic and political
instabilities in South-Central regions of Somalia. The ARC/Consortium consisted Save the Children,
SPARK, and Care Netherlands. Major findings of the labor market analysis provided to the ARC/Consortium
program proposal option.

**Consultant at Gargaar Organization** *January 2016 - February 2016 (2 months)*

Evaluated the impacts a piloted vocational training activities under Gragaar SHGs program, supported by
TearsFund.

**Senior Consultant at Health Agro-Pastoralists Education Liaison (HEAL)** *December 2015 - January 2016 (2 months)*

Successfully developed a concept paper on behalf of HEAL, which was approved and endorsed by CRC
Somalia WASH Cluster. 2.Developed on behalf of HEAL a WASH proposal, which approved by Unicef/
Somalia/WASH Section.

**Seniro and Lead Consultant at SPARK** *August 2015 - October 2015 (3 months)*

Lead Researcher on Local Employment for African Development (LEAD) Program, Dutch Foreign Trade
Cooperation Affairs supported Programme in relation to creating sustainable local economic growth for
sustainable employment for the Somali Youth.

**Senior Consultant at Katuni Consult Cooperative (KCC)** *August 2014 - December 2014 (5 months)*

Lead Researcher on DFID Supported Research on: Exploring Strategy for Community-Driven Negotiated
Accountability between District Level Structures and Citizens: An Operational Research Pilot Study

**Lead Consultant at Katuni Consult Cooperative (KCC)** *May 2014 - August 2014 (4 months)*

Lead Researcher on 12 UNDP Supported Micro-Projects for Assessment Development Results (ADRs) on
behalf of UNDP Independent Evaluation Office (IEO) New-York, USA

**Lead Consultant at Social Impact** *May 2013 - December 2013 (8 months)*

Lead Researcher in Somaliland and Puntland under Prime Contracts of Care Somalia Girls Education
Promotion Program (SOMGEP) and Relief International Educate Girls, End Poverty Project

**Senior Program Advisor at Health Education Agro-pastoralist Liaison (HEAL)** *September 2010 - April 2013 (2 years 8 months)*

Built the overall capacity of HEAL staff, developed working strategies and concurrent plan-of action with
various international partner organizations including the UN agencies such as UNDP/Somalia and UNICEF
Somalia, developed various proposals regarding poverty reduction and community health and education
developments and was responsible the overall organizational growth of HEAL.

**Lead Consultant at GARGAAR** *June 2011 - October 2012 (1 year 5 months)*

Monitored the progress of Access to Basic Education project and evaluated Community Based Literacy and
Livelihood Development (CBLLD) Project

**Lead Consultant at Somali Consultants Association (SOCA)** *December 2009 - August 2010 (9 months)*

Assisted the selection of sub-project proposals in regard to UNDP Employment Generation for Early
Recovery (EGER) Program, monitored implementation activities of 8 Somaliland local partner organization
with the UNDP EGER Program, developed strategies and monitoring and evaluation framework for SOCA,
designed and facilitated capacity building workshops for UNDP local partner organizations with the focus
on project planning, project monitoring and project evaluation , conducted various joint monitoring fieldtrips
with all stakeholders including the UNDP Hargeisa on the progress of all UNDP/EGER sub-projects,
designed and facilitated various community meetings for UNDP/EGER sponsored sub-projects and prepared
and produced weekly progress, midterm and project evaluation reports in relation to socioeconomic UNDP/
EGER sub- projects outcomes and wider project impacts

**Lead Consultant at Daryeel Bulsho Guud (DBG Somalia)** *March 2010 - May 2010 (3 months)*

Designed and facilitated strategic planning workshop for DBG, developed an updated DBG profile and
brochures of the organization, assisted the development of six months plan of action, designed and
facilitated capacity building workshop on various monitoring & evaluation methods and have produced
emergency preparedness strategy and specific participatory monitoring & evaluation tools for DBG

**Lead Consultant at Tools for Humanity (Tools4humanity)** *January 2009 - December 2009 (1 year)*

Carried-out situational assessment on the viability of opening new office site in Hargeisa, Somaliland,
established strong public relations with communities and with government and appropriate line-ministries,
planned/facilitated/reported several familiarization meetings and workshops about the core objectives of
Tools for Humanity and successfully situated Tools4 Humanity to operate in Somaliland

**Research Coordinator and Program Advisor at Life and Peace Institute** *February 2008 - June 2008 (5 months)*

Produced monthly situational analysis with possible scenarios, contributed and provided advice the
appropriateness of the two year LPI Somalia Conflict Transformation Programme, undertook quarterly
thorough conflict analysis in examining conflict dynamics and actors involved, undertook monitoring and
evaluation the conflict transformation capacity building program for Somali civil society organizations and
increased the capacity of local partner organizations to undertake baseline research that included effective
conflict analyses, monitoring and evaluating peacebuilding programs and building local partner’s capacity to
engage specific themes for further peace advocacy

**Senior Research Officer at Life and Peace Institute (LPI)** *June 2007 - January 2008 (8 months)*

Undertook documentation research on the role of Somali women peacebuilding activities, undertook
identification and assessment activity of potential local partners and facilitated workshops for agents
of change including Somali National Reconciliation Commission (NRC) and Baidoa Somali Women
Association

**Project Manager at Somali Peace Line (SPL)** *January 2007 - May 2007 (5 months)*

Managed the project in accordance with project objectives ,monitored and insured project activities be
implemented, Produced monthly reports on project activities , produced periodic situational analysis
undertook need assessment for newly IDPs in Mogadishu outskirts and facilitated peacebuilding workshops
for Benadir traditional elders

**Lead Technical Consultant at Care Somalia and Southern Sudan** *February 2007 - March 2007 (2 months)*

Developed and facilitated peace promotion workshops for Somali National Reconciliation Commission

**Researcher at Broderskapsrörelsen-The Christian Social Democrats in Sweden** *December 2006 - January 2007 (2 months)*

Researched on behalf of Broderskapsrörelsen “Major Challenges and Possibilities of the Somali Civil
Society” and presented findings in a workshop session under the workshop title Co-operation between
Sweden and Somalia with key stakeholders at Hotel Pan Africa Hotel in Nairobi, Kenya.


_____

**Summary**

#### PROFESSIONAL PROFILE Summary

Recently, and through indicative research, I have been working on how to create alternatives to humanitarian
aid in Somalia. Major findings include that it is possible to change currently channeling funds of the UN
for humanitarian aid and directly investing in the private sector and through creating debt less funding
mechanism. One method is creating inclusive global markets and by enabling Somalia's markets with the
private investments of both local and international investments.

In addition, I have a solid research background in which extensively researched on relief, recovery , and
development-related interventions in Somalia including Somaliland. Major researched issues include
researching drivers of social, economic and political instabilities of Somalia.

Furthermore, have effectively contributed the development of a relevant monitoring and evaluation
frameworks. As the result, produced number of locally applicable survey instruments for qualitative and
quantitative studies through household surveys, focus group discussions relating to food security, employment
creation, health, and education interventions.Due to 10 years of experience, I have developed new threshold
that addresses major drivers of such protracted violent conflict in Somalia. The core function of the developed
threshold is through identifying program stakeholders and creating effective linkages of such identified
program stakeholders. Throughout my working experience, I also have documented major lessons learned on
peacebuilding approaches, political economy and on sustainable local development. Major Goal: contributing

fields.name: Somalia
fields.short_description: is located in the Horn of Africa, on the Indian Ocean coast
fields.long_description: Somalia is located in East Africa and bordered Indian Ocean to the east, Kenya to the south, Ethiopia to the West, Djibouti to the north-west and Red Sea to north.

fields.name: Djibouti
fields.short_description: is located in East Africa, on the coast of Red Sea
fields.long_description: Djibouti is located in the mouth of Bab-Al-Mandab, which is a channel between Yemen and Djibouti.

fields.name: Ethiopia
fields.short_description: is located in East Africa, on the highland of Habesha
fields.long_description: Ethiopia is located in East Africa, and is land-locked country which has borders with Djibouti, Somalia, Kenya, South-Sudan, Sudan and Eritrea.

fields.name: Kenya
fields.short_description: is located in East Africa and is founding member of East African Community
fields.long_description: Kenya is located in East Africa and has borders with Somalia, Tanzania, Uganda, South-Sudan and Ethiopia.

fields.name: Uganda
fields.short_description: is located in East Africa and is member of East African Community
fields.long_description: Uganda is located in East Afica and has borders with South-Sudan, Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda and Brundi.

fields.name: Eritrea
fields.short_description: is located in East Africa on the coast of Red Sea
fields.long_description: Eritrea is located in East Africa and has borders with Sudan, Djibouti and Ethiopia.

fields.name: esdi detail
fields.short_description: EcoSocial Dynamics International (ESDI) is a USA-based private consultancy company that advises governments, international organizations, and private corporations in the Horn of Africa (HoA)
fields.long_description:
EcoSocial Dynamics International (ESDI) is a USA-based private consultancy company that advises governments, international organizations, and private corporations 
in the Horn of Africa (HoA) on how to improve the livelihood of the peoples of the region. Based on hard data, the region has many favorable eco-social systems that can comfortably 
sustain the population. However, despite its natural endowments, the HoA is one of the most inhospitable regions in the world.


The Horn of Africa is a tapestry of ecology and cultures that have traditionally complemented one another. In recent years new faulty lines have appeared in the tapestry—i.e., worsening state-society relations, dwindling resources, tribal wars, terrorism, and mass displacement of peoples. Left unaddressed for so many years, these have severely reduced the habitability of the HoA. Mass migration and internal displacement of peoples are common occurrences.

fields.name: what we do
fields.short_description: ESDI MONITORS THE DRIVERS OF ECO-SOCIAL CHALLENGES:
fields.long_description:
-
Climate Change

Weak governance systems

Over exploitation of the commons

Social strife

Recurrent famine

fields.name: how we do
fields.short_description: IN DEVELOPING POLICY FRAMEWORK WE EMPHASIZES ON:
fields.long_description:
-
Environmental rehabilitation

Protection of the fragile ecology

Good governance

Capacity building

Inter-communal dialogue and reconciliation
